name: Fig Tree
displayName: Fig Tree - Symbol of Israel and Torah Meditation
shortDescription: Sacred tree symbolizing Israel, peace, prosperity, and Torah study; where Jesus saw Nathanael meditating before calling him as apostle
fullDescription: The fig tree (Ficus carica) carries profound spiritual significance across Jewish and Christian traditions. In the Hebrew Bible, the fig tree symbolizes the nation of Israel (Hosea 9:10), peace and prosperity ('every man under his vine and fig tree' - 1 Kings 4:25, Micah 4:4), and the blessings of the Promised Land (Deuteronomy 8:8). In rabbinic tradition, the fig tree became associated with Torah study - sages would sit beneath fig trees to meditate on Scripture, as the tree provides continuous fruit throughout season (representing ongoing study) and abundant shade. This context illuminates Jesus's statement to Nathanael: 'Before Philip called you, when you were under the fig tree, I saw you' (John 1:48). Jesus recognized Nathanael engaged in Torah meditation, preparing spiritually for the Messiah's coming. The fig tree thus connects Jewish piety with Christian fulfillment. Jesus's cursing of the barren fig tree (Mark 11:12-25) represents judgment on Israel for failing to produce the fruit of righteousness despite the season of Messiah's coming. The fig tree's leaves, used by Adam and Eve to cover their nakedness (Genesis 3:7), connect it to humanity's original shame and the need for divine covering.

mythologyContexts.symbolism: The fig tree embodies Israel's covenant relationship with God. When flourishing, it represents divine blessing and national prosperity. When barren or destroyed, it symbolizes judgment. The rabbinic tradition of studying Torah under fig trees connects the tree to spiritual wisdom. The fig's unique characteristic of bearing fruit before leaves made Jesus's cursing of the leafy but fruitless tree particularly significant - all show, no substance.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Fig trees are one of the Seven Species of the Land of Israel (Deuteronomy 8:8). Sitting under one's vine and fig tree became shorthand for peaceful, prosperous existence. The image pervades Jewish liturgy and hope for messianic redemption.

mythologyContexts.usage: Symbol connecting Jewish piety to messianic recognition; judgment on fruitlessness; eschatological sign

textReferences.context: Jesus sees Nathanael under the fig tree - divine foreknowledge
Jesus curses the barren fig tree; linked to Temple cleansing
Parable of the barren fig tree given one more year
Fig tree's leaves signaling summer - eschatological teaching

mythologyContexts.symbolism: In Christian interpretation, the fig tree's connection to Nathanael highlights Jewish spiritual preparation for Christ. His Torah meditation bore fruit in immediate recognition of Jesus as Messiah. The cursed fig tree represents Israel's (or humanity's) failure to produce righteousness despite abundant religious observance. The fig tree parable emphasizes God's patience but ultimate demand for spiritual fruit.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: The fig tree narrative in John 1 has become a model for evangelical calling - God knows us in our seeking before we know Him. The cursing of the fig tree generated extensive allegorical interpretation about faith, fruitfulness, and judgment in Christian tradition.
